children.subject:
Whoa ive been in a similar position to you in wanting to take these courses but not having enough space in my schedule to do so.

I also feel like 127 is a cool class and me taking it just for 189 prep wouldnt do it as much justice as me just studying some matrix calculus and whatnot. I am fortunate to be taking 53 this summer to make up for my non-existent multivar knowledge but lmk if you want to self-study 127 with me anytime — I think you could probably just go into it with just 16a rn and learn whatever else you need on the way (that's what ive been doing). I also feel like learning some multivar like vector calc is kinda orthogonal to doing ML but i don't know much haha

Ive also heard that 186 is more like making ancient databases/counting IOs which may me less applicable than what you think but if you really wanna learn that, I'm down to study it as well :)

Feel free to msg me on any platform, my handle is probs rsha256 :)
are there any special topics in optimization you would recommend focusing on? what about linear algebra topics? I'm having trouble fitting in these courses so just trying to optimize (ha) my studying

not familiar with 186, but if you're just focused on 189, you can definitely get by with a light self-study of 127 material -> mainly just getting familiar with linear algebra a bit beyond 16AB (or math 54) level and the idea of an optimization problem. You'd miss out on deeper understanding of optimization but it would be sufficient for understanding 189 content.

186 is ...  kind of a weird class to me. On one hand, it does teach you a lot about the basics of relational databases (and some of the NoSQL alternatives towards the end), so after taking it SQL queries would probably make a little more sense to you. But on the other hand, it focuses more on the implementation of databases, not so much on how to use them effectively, so essentially its usefulness depends on how often one needs to make its own version of SQL. Maybe it is better designed for people who want to go into research in similar fields.

history.content:
tl;dr how can I self-learn EECS127 or general databases content-- which one's easier to self-teach?

rising senior in CS, taking the fall semester off to do an internship, and plan on graduating either next spring or summer. I decided that I want to learn about machine learning™ after all, but haven't done any of the prereqs so just trying to figure how I can take advantage of my remaining one semester and free time. I still have to take 2 CS courses and one technical elective (could also be CS) before I graduate.

Motivation for learning 127 is having prep for 189, motivation for 186 is because... idk apparently databases are pretty important. So I don't even need Berkeley 186 specifically, just any course that will get me familiar with DB stuff before I graduate. I will be entering the industry as a SWE but looking to continue my education and maybe pivot to other positions later. Any thoughts appreciated!

Some options:

Fall 2021Spring 2022Summer 2022
Internship, Math 53 @ CC, self-learn EECS127CS189, CS186last tech elective
Internship, Math 53 @ CC, self-learn databasesCS189, EECS127last tech elective
Internship, Math 53 @ CCCS189, EECS127CS186 (idk if this is even possible over the summer)

With all the Spring 22 options, I'm hoping to do some research. Which one sounds more doable, and does anyone have any advice? Thanks in advance c:
history.subject: self-learning EECS127 or CS186
